repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Agricultural
            Services Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the assessment of the project
            is unsatisfactory. Contrary to the benefits expected at
            appraisal time, institutional benefits were limited, while
            socio-economic benefits were not properly evaluated, and
            remain seemingly limited. Furthermore, although monitoring
            and evaluation does indicate some increase in crops'
            productivity, the establishment of agricultural production
            benefits was not clearly defined, and, such increase may not
            be attributed to the adoption of improved technology
            methods. Likewise, the project did not provide indicators to
            measure the impact from environmental benefits. The major
            lessons suggest, that while this project raises questions
            regarding supervision accessibility in a country suffering
            civil unrest, still, project design should address more
            precise monitoring and evaluation indicators. Special
            attention should be given, when considering centralized
            technical ministries for execution of crucial agricultural
            research and extension projects, as efficiency may be poor,
            whereas, decentralized, autonomous agencies may prove more
            efficient. In addition, project design may need to phase the
            project progressively, i.e., 1) institutional set-up; 2)
            capacity building; 3) research and extension operations,
            and, procurement work. The responsibility for operational
            costs should be clearly stated, particularly, when
            suspension occurs, to avoid exceptional expenses.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Agricultural
            Services Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The projects main objectives are: (i) to
            set up permanent rural support services at a cost to
            Government that will eventually become sustainable without
            outside assistance and, (ii) to support the tendency among
            local people to organize themselves in groups to manage
            village affairs.  Project benefits are of two orders: first,
            the building of stronger, better coordinated agricultural
            institutions which will operate at lower costs than the sum
            total of the fragmented, sometimes overlapping donor-funded
            interventions that prevailed so far; second, improvements in
            the livelihood of rural people, made possible by project
            actions designed to increase agricultural productivity and
            create artisanal employment.  Since women provide the
            majority of labor for crop maintenance and processing, the
            successful extension of labor saving technologies will be of
            particular benefit to them by reducing their workload.
            Through the community participation approach, villages will
            become increasingly more efficient at managing their own
            affairs.  The educated rural youths are expected to gain
            responsibility and social status as a result.  Other equally
            significant benefits are expected to arise from the
            emergence of numerous, varied trading and artisanal
            activities which will stimulate exchanges and monetize the
            economy in the project area.
